intro: Piqueria attenuata, commonly known as the Mexican buttercup, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, showcasing adaptations to dry climates. Its flowers are yellow with a central disk, and it produces small, elongated fruits called achenes. Piqueria attenuata is often found in rocky soils and is sometimes used in traditional medicine.
